headline: Senate GOP privately roots against Trump in Ohio primary
author: Alexander Bolton
sentences: If he doesnt win, we will exploit that for everything its worth and say the Trump endorsement isnt the be-all, end-all it once was and maybe now we can get some breathing room from the craziness,? said a senior Senate GOP aide, who said that 70 percent of Senate Republicans share this sentiment, though only few of them would dare to say so publicly.

Cruz said he doesnt think a Vance loss would mean Trump is losing his grip on the GOP but predicted that Im sure the press will write it up that way.?

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) celebrated what he thought was Trumps political demise after he appeared to incite a crowd of supporters to storm the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, in an attempt to stall the certification of President Bidens victory.

McConnell reportedly felt exhilarated? about Trumps apparent political implosion, telling a reporter for The New York Times that he thought Trump had effectively put a gun to his head and pulled the trigger,? according to a new book by Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns.

Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), who is eyeing a presidential run in 2024, campaigned for Vances opponent, former state Treasurer Josh Mandel, over the weekend.

Justin Buchler, a political science professor at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, said Trumps impact on Vances surge in the polls has been overstated because his numbers started ticking up before Trump made his endorsement.

Buchler said Trumps endorsements in Senate primaries keeps him politically active and the center of the Republican universe.?
Whats interesting and puzzling to me is how frequently he has missed the mark with his endorsements,? he said.

A Trafalgar Group poll conducted among GOP primary voters on April 13 and April 14, before Trump made his endorsement public, showed Vance in second place with 22.6 percent support, trailing then-front-runner Mandel by 5 points.

My philosophy on endorsements is I look for the strongest conservative who can win, and I spent two days this weekend campaigning with Josh in Ohio.

A second Republican aide said it will be fun to watch? if a non-Trump-backed candidate wins the Ohio Senate primary and predicted that if Matt Dolan wins, it will create a buzz among Senate Republicans.
A Republican Trafalgar Group poll conducted from April 29 to May 1 showed Vance leading with 26 percent support, followed by Dolan with 22 percent, Mandel with 21 percent and Gibbons with 13 percent.
